Two friends reused a prime when generating their RSA keys. Recover the message: 8006927664512608443546551029349248823381015604822420550774020063653858260063176948874245370863635999459138362984025005373951293001375136030655802753072107

n=9468265438609447259378412037446360259791948869550113686575626090171668534107215429610230553202835005650670786392283895496701836179617642392190994216985009, n2=6790281467914375756463389072965469816441135531019623412330742787683533895398189805372297270369849215503301038970013234096946950195727608323675581613917793, e=2017440151831602267087350597594554191136602543658153268191485986421691546814351934909969594077079322613719010013295230877702233742151393645006796752631893

---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{3gj10rh0}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 8006927664512608443546551029349248823381015604822420550774020063653858260063176948874245370863635999459138362984025005373951293001375136030655802753072107
vulnerability: shared prime
hint: When two RSA moduli share a common prime, computing GCD(n, n2) can reveal the shared prime factor.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
